metadata.title: Exploratory Data Analysis. Exploratory data Analysis | by Nitin Mahajan | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: In this post we’ll walk through a number of different `Python` functions, methods and attributes using Pandas library, which are important right after uploading the data for exploratory data analysis…

all_paragraphs: In this post we’ll walk through a number of different `Python` functions, methods and attributes using Pandas library, which are important right after uploading the data for exploratory data analysis (EDA). However, the purpose of this article is to get maximum of information by running minimum commands. After reading this post one’ll be able to spend less time to get an idea about the data set and more time exploring and modeling.
To share my understanding of the concept, I’ll take an example of California housing price data set.

Most of the time, we start our EDA by running following methods (written in black), however, if we look closely, we can run only two methods (written in blue)and can get all the information which we get after running all these.
This function returns information about the dataframe including the data types of each column and memory usage of the entire data.
What information we can collect from df.info():
(i) It will print out the data type of the object, which is a Pandas dataframe.<class ‘pandas.core.frame.DataFrame’>
(ii) Number of entries, or rows, in the dataframe, and the range of values of the row indexes. Remember — Here the first index is 0 and the last index is (n-1)RangeIndex: 20640 entries, 0 to 20639
(iii) Information about each data column, including the column names, number of entries, whether they have non-null values, and the data type.
(iv) Number of columns per datatype in the dataframe. dtypes: float64(9), object(1)
(v) At the end, it shows the memory usage of the dataframe.memory usage: 1.6+ MB
4 in 1: Apart from the information mentioned above df.info() provides all the information we can get after running these four — len(df), df.shape, df.isnull, df.dtypes().
This method provides a summary statistics like average, standard deviation and quantile values from the data frame which plays a very critical role to understand data distribution of each column.
Pandas provides an option, where we can se the the above table in transpose manner by using the transpose function.
In addition, there are certain summary columns like “count of unique values” which can be printed by passing option include = ‘all’ to describe method as follows.
Now we know how to get a brief statistical summary of numerical variables using describe() method. But, what if we have categorical data? The value_counts() method will be helpful in this case.

Remember — df.describe() will only give summary for the numerical variables [or if we pass exclude=’O’ as parameter i.e df.describe(exclude=’O’)]. Moreover, if we are interested only in categorical columns, we can pass include=’O’.
The statistics give us an idea about attributes containing missing values, the average value and maximum for a particular attribute, which will be useful when we preprocess and build our model.
4 in 1: Apart from the information mentioned above df.describe() provides all the information we can get after running these four - len(df), df.shape, df.isnull, df.dtypes().

This doesn't mean that these methods / functions /attributes [(len(df), df.shape, df.isnull, df.dtypes()] discussed here are not useful. One should keep in mind that, they have their own importance especially when you are interested in knowing the details about your variable(s). For examples, if you have 30 columns, and you want to know the dtype of say ‘abc’ column, you can run the info, but it would be wise to run the df[‘abc’].dtpyes() to know only dtype of that particular variable instead.
Below, I have presented use of functions/attributes discussed above.

This attribute gives the dimension of the dataframe (df.shape gives a tuple with (n_rows, n_columns)). Shape also covers the length of the data frame, which means running df.shape will also give information which one can get from len(df) during EDA.
df.shape[0] or len(df.index) also give the total number of rows. To know the number of columns in the data frame, we can use len(df.columns) or df.shape[1].
All the data types are in a dataframe can be printed using df.dtypes.

Other commonly used methods during EDA are df.head( ) or df.tail() which return the top 5 and bottom 5 rows of data. The default number in pandas is five (5), however one can change as required, by simply entering the number in the parentheses. For example df.head(3) will give top three rows and df.tail(10) will give bottom 10 rows of the dataset.
I hope, after reading this post one’ll be able to spend less time to get an idea about the data set and more time exploring and modeling.
Enjoy EDA and Thanks for reading 😄.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
